Message from GHS Principal Matt Durst to Parents of the Class of 2020:

I am writing today with an update on the status of the revised graduation video and diplomas. Many thanks to Mike Yearling for his outstanding work on the initial graduation video and his time working in live video segments after the drive-thru ceremony. We have housed the original and revised videos on the high school website: https://www.granvilleschools.org/GraduationDetails.aspx . Once at the site, you will need to wait a few minutes for the videos to cache. Then, both are available for viewing and download. I highly suggest each family download and save a copy of both videos to view at their leisure.

Diplomas for the class of 2020 are set to be mailed home to graduates on Monday, August 3.

IMPORTANT: If your residential mailing address is now different than what you entered in Final Forms for the 2019-20 school year, please email Kathy Frank (kfrank@granvilleschools.org) with the updated address. If your address has not changed, no action is required.

GHS Theatre – Together in Spirit!

The GHS Theatre has spent time together in unique ways during this time. The cast, crew and pit of Into to Woods honored our show week by still wearing show shirts each day of the week that should have been our opening night and created colleagues at the end of each day. We created a fan video to celebrate what we would have created for our spring musical. We held a cast party over zoom and viewed the video together, shared some memories and shed some tears. The event was followed by the tradition of a senior circle in a non-traditional way.

The drama club will gather again over zoom for an end of the year event and slide show. This will take the place of what is usually our Drama Awards night when we induct new thespians and give other thespian awards, announce Oscar awards for the year, and celebrate our seniors. In addition, the group has also gathered several times to play theatre trivia to stay connected during this difficult time and remind ourselves that we remain Together in Spirit!

The U.S. Census count of 2020 begins April 1, and it’s critical for every Ohioan to be counted. Why? An incomplete count could affect our state’s schools, families and students.

Population numbers make an impact on a state’s federal funding for quality-of-life areas like education, public safety, highways and health care. Districts, schools and educators can play a vital role in the success of the 2020 census by encouraging school families to take part, especially those associated with hard-to-count populations such as young children, immigrants, low-income households and people with limited access to computers.

Mrs. Durham's class is spending the month of March learning about wonderful worms and how much they can help the environment around them. As part of this study, in early April, they will be going to the other classrooms in the building to share with them about what they have learned. If you have any of these bottles at home, please remove the labels and send them in with your students and they can place them in the bin in the front of the school.

If you can contribute bottles to help with this awesome project it would be appreciated!

post_text: Please take some time over the long weekend to visit the downtown area of Granville. Around the center you will see the hearts that our 4th grade students created for their PBL Kindness Project. Students were asked the driving question, "How do we share kindness in our community?" For the project, the students decorated paper hearts with quotes and then visited two local retirement communities to interview residents. During this time, students asked them to share stories of how an act of kindness has impacted their lives. These audio recorded interviews will be transcribed, placed into a book, and shared with our students' new friends when the 4th grade classes visit the retirement communities again in April. A sincere thank you to all of our families who were able to volunteer to help with this memorable experience.
